channel.title: SevenAtSevenPolitics
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from SevenAtSevenPolitics, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Trump attracts America's billionaires to bankroll policies and projects
item.description: President Trump loves billionaires, and they seemingly love him, too. America's wealthiest have all but lined up to fund the president's pet projects ...

item.title: 'Nothing really happens': Lawmakers frustrated about inaction on kids' online safety bills
item.description: Lawmakers are tired of teaming up on bipartisan bills to protect kids online, only to have the broadly supported measures languish.

item.title: Meta's new AI privacy policy allows targeted ads, possibly political ads, based on chats with bots
item.description: Some Instagram users may start seeing that political advertisements mirror what they say and search on the social media platform.

item.title: It’s Not Just Minnesota. The Vast Majority Of Daycare Is A Scam
item.description: Taxpayers have spent hundreds of billions more on completely ineffective daycare than even Somalis have been able to pilfer.

item.title: Trump administration ends lease for three golf courses in the District
item.description: The Trump administration has ended the lease agreement with the National Links Trust for three golf courses in the District.

item.title: China’s global aggression check: Taiwan tensions, military posturing and US response in 2025
item.description: China-Taiwan tensions reach new heights as Beijing conducts largest military drills, responding to massive $11 billion U.S. arms package for Taipei.

item.title: A year after DOGE, the cuts keep coming

item.title: White House race underway: With 2026 looming, both parties are already playing for 2028
item.description: The 2028 White House race heats up as JD Vance gets major endorsement while Kamala Harris and Gavin Newsom make strategic moves at Democratic summit.

item.title: It’s New Year’s Day 2026. What’s open and closed?
item.description: Most federal services are shuttered, but the retail landscape remains mixed.

item.title: Mark Cuban says he doesn’t do calls and prefers email because ‘if we do it by phone, I’m going to forget half the stuff that we talked about’
item.description: Meanwhile, Gen Zers prefer email or text because of their anxiety about talking on the phone.

item.title: Black Republican calls for total, permanent abolition of DEI: 'I want to earn every opportunity on merit'
item.description: Black Republican U.S. Rep. Wesley Hunt of Texas called for the full and permanent abolition of diversity, equity, and inclusion ideology.

item.title: CEOs say they are unplugging from the top job by cancelling all meetings and playing with Legos over the holidays
item.description: The leaders behind tech companies and multimillion-dollar cookie empires weigh in on work-life balance during the holidays—from strict screen time lim...

item.title: What the Debates over American Heritage Are Really About
item.description: The wars that someone’s ancestors fought in are beside the point.

item.description: Trump has signed more executive orders in 2025 than in all four years of his first term combined. It's unclear whether many of them can survive court ...

item.title: An Exorbitant Burden
item.description: Not today, but tomorrow, Uncle Sam is broke. Point the blame at fiat currency.

item.title: Without George Washington, America Wouldn’t Have A 250th Birthday
item.description: No one looms larger in the story of our nation's struggle for independence than George Washington, who today seems almost mythical.

item.title: When New Art’s Really Old: From the Valley of the Kings to Pompeii to a Rubens in a Paris Closet
item.description: Some of 2025’s biggest art discoveries, plus the Swamp art scene spills into 2026.

item.title: Feds are hunting teenage hacking groups like ‘Scattered Spider’ who have targeted $1 trillion worth of the Fortune 500 since 2022
item.description: Rogue teens have attacked some 120 companies—including Nike, Chick-fil-A, Instacart, and News Corporation—often posing as IT staff.

item.description: The team has approached its most distinctive economic policy in a way that maximizes its ability to negotiate, but not its ability to play defense.
